text: What is your organization's role with respect to the general-purpose AI (GPAI) model used in this product?

options.label: GPAI model provider
options.description: You develop, train, and/or distribute the GPAI model itself

options.label: GPAI model deployer
options.description: You integrate a third-party GPAI model (e.g., Claude, GPT-4, Gemini) into your product

options.label: Both provider and deployer
options.description: You both develop your own GPAI model and deploy third-party GPAI models

regulatoryRelevance: EU AI Act Articles 53-55 impose different obligations on GPAI model providers vs. deployers. Providers have documentation, copyright, and training data obligations; deployers must verify provider compliance.

text: What is the name of the GPAI model(s) your product uses or provides?
regulatoryRelevance: Identifying the specific GPAI model is needed for technical documentation and to assess whether it exceeds systemic risk thresholds under Article 51.

text: Is the GPAI model released under a free and open-source licence with publicly available weights and architecture?
regulatoryRelevance: Article 53(2) provides a partial exemption from GPAI provider obligations for open-source models â€” but this exemption does NOT apply if the model has systemic risk.

text: Was the GPAI model trained using cumulative compute of 10^25 FLOPs (floating point operations) or more?

options.label: Yes
options.description: Training compute meets or exceeds 10^25 FLOPs

options.label: Unknown
options.description: Training compute is not publicly known or disclosed

regulatoryRelevance: Article 51 classifies GPAI models as having systemic risk if training compute exceeds 10^25 FLOPs. This triggers additional obligations under Article 55 (model evaluation, adversarial testing, risk assessment, incident reporting, cybersecurity).

text: Has the European Commission designated this GPAI model as having systemic risk?
regulatoryRelevance: Under Article 51(2), the Commission can designate a GPAI model as having systemic risk even if it falls below the compute threshold, based on criteria in Annex XIII.

text: Do you provide documentation to downstream AI system providers who integrate your GPAI model, covering capabilities, limitations, and integration guidance?
regulatoryRelevance: Article 53(1)(b) requires GPAI providers to make available information and documentation to downstream providers to enable them to understand the model's capabilities and limitations.

text: Do you have a policy in place to comply with EU copyright law, including respecting text and data mining opt-outs?
regulatoryRelevance: Article 53(1)(c) requires all GPAI providers to put in place a policy to comply with Union copyright law, specifically Directive (EU) 2019/790 Article 4(3) regarding text and data mining opt-outs.

text: Have you prepared and made publicly available a sufficiently detailed summary of the content used for training the GPAI model?
regulatoryRelevance: Article 53(1)(d) requires GPAI providers to draw up and make publicly available a training data summary according to a template provided by the AI Office.

text: Does the GPAI model have an acceptable use policy that defines prohibited and restricted uses?
regulatoryRelevance: While not explicitly mandated by a single article, an acceptable use policy is a best practice for GPAI providers to mitigate misuse risk and demonstrate due diligence under Articles 53-55.
